{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3487977,"name":"Jake","username":"_j_kot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T07:11:17.678Z","cooked":"

Hello,

We’ve recently transitioned to using carnivore for our swerve drive due to deprecation of Phoenix 5, but we are having some issues with CANivore. The first thing that we noticed is an error message in console “CAN Frame not received/too-stale”, even though the robot would drive and work fine. Other signs are; CANivore status light blinking red fast but sometime’s blinks green, all motors blink red. Here is a video of this weird occurrence. The weird part is that it seems to fine as long as only one swerve module is connected, and we can connect Pigeon2 and other stuff to it. As long as it is not another swerve module, it seems to be fine.

What I’ve tried:
Connect different roborio - Did not help
Connect directly to roborio without CANivore - helped
Connecting only one swerve module (2 Krackens and a CAN Coder) - works just fine.

Any ideas/recommendations?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T07:11:17.678Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":109.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Jake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://streamable.com/pf2nv1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Watch video_2025-01-20_02-02-20 | Streamable","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70713,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coding Lead"},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/1","custom_user_title":"Coding Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3487995,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T08:49:58.279Z","cooked":"

CAN FD used by the CANivore is 10Mbps, compared to the regular CAN speed of 1Mbps. This makes it about 10X more susceptible to signal integrity issues. I would make sure everything is up to date (since that’s relatively easy) but it’s most likely a wiring issue.

You can disconnect the terminating resistor from the end of the chain (make sure you have that first), and start working your way down the chain. Once you add something to the chain and it starts blinking red, either the latest thing you added has issues, or the cumulative signal degradation from small issues have added up to a bad signal. You can then check that same device/group of devices separately to figure out which of those it is.

_j_kot:

We’ve recently transitioned to using carnivore for our swerve drive due to deprecation of Phoenix 5

CANivore isn’t necessary to use Phoenix 6. Is there more to the story of why you switched?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T14:22:13.277Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":26.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488339,"name":"Jake","username":"_j_kot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T19:34:13.939Z","cooked":"

We switched because it allows for more features with phoenix 6. Oficial Phoenix 6 features breakdown. Specifically for Swerve API features.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T19:50:24.107Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":20.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Jake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/migration/new-to-phoenix.html#feature-breakdown","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Phoenix 6 Features","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70713,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coding Lead"},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/4","custom_user_title":"Coding Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488361,"name":"Jake","username":"_j_kot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T19:46:22.825Z","cooked":"

Everything is up to date, I’ve checked that multiple times and even reinstall updates. I tried tracing multiple times and from different ends/parts but everything stays the same untill it comes down to one swerve module. It does not matter which one or in which one it is, or which pair i try to connect, once one swerve module gets connected to another it starts having issues. I will have a video of that tommorow. That is why I said it is a “weird” issue. I’ve checked wiering many times but it seeems all good, the only way it could be better is if I solder it. We also dont use terminating resistor but rather end with a PDH.

Any other ideas?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T19:46:22.825Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":34.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Jake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":66264,"username":"Ryan_Reed","name":"Ryan Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70713,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coding Lead"},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/5","custom_user_title":"Coding Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488410,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T20:37:56.325Z","cooked":"

Have you checked the CAN IDs for all the devices to ensure that there are not duplicates for each type of device?

Have you tried only having that one swerve module connected between the Roborio and the PDH?

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T20:37:56.325Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":55,"readers_count":54,"score":16.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":70713,"username":"_j_kot","name":"Jake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488458,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T21:32:07.453Z","cooked":"

I don’t think the PDH supports CAN FD. That could be sending a bunch of error frames.

I would use a terminating resistor, like so:

terminating resistor1194×1704 183 KB

It looks like you use a different connector but the concept is the same.

Also seconding philso on the CAN IDs

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T21:33:01.719Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":48,"readers_count":47,"score":14.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Ryan Reed","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":70713,"username":"_j_kot","name":"Jake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488499,"name":"Jake","username":"_j_kot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T22:19:50.810Z","cooked":"

All the CAN IDs are different, they would be red in Turner X if there would be duplicates, and they wouldn’t show up. But yes, all IDs are different, and I double-checked that.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T22:19:50.810Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":33,"readers_count":32,"score":26.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482715,"topic_slug":"weird-can-issues","display_username":"Jake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":15467,"username":"philso","name":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70713,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coding Lead"},"post_url":"/t/weird-can-issues/482715/9","custom_user_title":"Coding Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488506,"name":"Jake","username":"_j_kot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_j_kot/{size}/242255_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T22:25:53.690Z","cooked":"

It does not matter which module is connected, as long as it is just one of them. But when connecting to roborio (instead of CANivore) everything works fine with everything connected. And yes, I noticed that disconnecting PDH stops error frames but does not fix the issue. I will try adding the resistor as termination tomorrow. We are using a bit of a different connector as they proved to be more sturdy.
